entry.title: Encountering the Unknown Self
entry.content:
Notes on Encountering the Unknown Self

What is the ‚ÄúUnknown‚Äù?

The ‚Äúself‚Äù refers to the ‚Äútrue self.‚Äù From the question ‚ÄúWho am I?‚Äù to the concept of ‚Äúfrom existence to non-existence,‚Äù the entire book is structured around dialogues between Ruoling and a wise elder, revealing many profound life concepts.

Core Concepts

  • There is no one outside‚Äîonly yourself.
    All external situations are actually projections of your inner world.

  • Golden Moments to Talk with the Subconscious
    The best times to imagine you‚Äôve already achieved your goals are the moments between waking and sleeping‚Äîearly morning just before fully waking up, or late at night before falling asleep. These times are when we are closest to our subconscious.

  • Key Practices: Awareness, Surrender, Overcoming the Peptide Self (Ego)

    • Awareness: Focus on your present self. Observe your emotions and reactions without judgment.
    • Surrender: Accept reality instead of resisting it.
    • Peptide Self (Ego): Represents inner voices of fear, comparison, and anxiety. Learn to recognize and transcend them.

  • Meditation, Gratitude, Giving

    • During meditation, visualize yourself already living your desired life.
    • Be grateful even before your goals are achieved.
    • Maintain a selfless, giving mindset.

  • Care Less About Others, Care More About Yourself

    • Bring your attention back to yourself and your inner world.
    • When emotions arise, be aware of which part of your body feels uncomfortable and understand its message.

Conclusion

This book is not only about discovering ‚Äúwho you are,‚Äù but also about reminding you to ‚Äúbecome that true self.‚Äù Awakening inner strength requires continuous awareness, practice, and transcending the ego.

entry.title: Reflections on *What I Talk About When I Talk About Running*
entry.content:
What I Talk About When I Talk About Running

It was through this book that I realized there could be another version of myself out there, doing something I love. Before reading this book, I had never read anything by Murakami. I knew he was popular and had many famous books, but I hadn‚Äôt really paid attention. But when it comes to running, I felt there could be a connection.

If I keep running, will I eventually reach the moon? Running isn‚Äôt about living longer, but about making life feel easier and lighter within the time we have.

I was surprised by Murakami‚Äôs imagination while running‚Äîso free and boundless. I really enjoy that. I‚Äôve imagined many things too, like suddenly recalling a lyric while running‚Äîsomething like ‚Äúspeeding up to chase happiness,‚Äù blabla‚Ä¶ Long-distance running requires endurance, but also imagination. Of course, the premise is loving to run. If someone doesn‚Äôt like running, no matter how much you say, it won‚Äôt matter. But if someone does love it, they‚Äôll even want to meet another version of themselves during a break in the rain. Humans are inherently lonely, but the spirit can resonate with others.

I plan to keep running no matter how the world changes. Once, I walked 30 kilometers in one day. Despite the sunburn, I loved the spiritual fulfillment more. If you haven‚Äôt experienced it, you have no voice. Maybe I‚Äôm like Chen Kun‚Äîa pessimistic optimist. I live actively in this world, but I also see through its illusions. Neither joyful because of things, nor sorrowful because of myself.

My pulse has dropped to just over 50 beats per minute. Seems like I‚Äôm built for jogging. After all, it‚Äôs about interest. As long as my freedom isn‚Äôt restricted, anything is acceptable.

I hope next year I‚Äôll join a marathon, with people cheering me on. That would be so happy.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a person, but a pure machine. So I don‚Äôt need to feel anything, just keep running forward.‚Äù

What‚Äôs most similar is that we both love to run non-stop. Not the type who walks when tired or stops to enjoy the scenery. Maybe people have different views, but I think the true king is the one who can keep running without stopping.

When reaching the finish line, I‚Äôd feel so cool, a rush of pride, like winning the lottery or getting incredibly lucky. It‚Äôs a principle‚Äîand also my pride.

Oh, right‚Äîjust like Brother Shang waiting at the finish line, and I‚Äôd smile proudly.

entry.title: Reflections on *Skin*
entry.content:
Aunt Tai

Aunt Tai is strong-willed and resilient. Her optimistic attitude is something worth learning from. The greatest thing my father ever did was marrying my mother‚Äîa truly great woman. A real woman should face everything with positivity and build the future she desires with her own hands.

Although she resorted to stealing, it was driven by hardship‚Äîsurvival and family. Setting aside pride to do things against her will is, in a way, a form of strength. It‚Äôs not about crying and making a scene, but staying proactive in adversity.

Thinking about it, the author‚Äôs achievements are inseparable from his great mother.

Ah, that lovely mother! To preserve her husband‚Äôs dignity and happiness, she insisted on completing the house. Isn‚Äôt that a form of strength too? To follow her heart courageously is truly admirable.

In fact, the person who understands my father the most is my mother. She knows his pride. Isn‚Äôt this what love is? You don‚Äôt need to say it‚ÄîI understand. I understand you, and you understand me, and that‚Äôs why we‚Äôve been together for so long.

Zhang Meili

Get up from where you fell. Zhang Meili seems like someone who pursued true love and worked hard for what she desired. Though she was eventually forced to liberate herself sexually, I still respect her for everything she once did.

Public opinion is powerful, but Zhang Meili‚Äôs inner strength is even more powerful.

entry.title: One Day You'll Understand - Reading Notes by Mr. Zhuomo
entry.content:
The book does contain a lot of his own ‚Äúbiases,‚Äù but I find him authentic and humorous. His language is simple and understandable, and each subtitle essentially tells us what we should do.

Understanding Life

Life is never about what you want it to be. It‚Äôs good to discover beauty and to view things from others‚Äô perspectives. At the same time, one should have self-awareness.

Understanding Love

Sheldon once said: ‚ÄúThe pursuit of another human to spend life with is something I‚Äôve never understood. Maybe I‚Äôm too interesting to need company. So I wish you the same joy with each other as I have with myself.‚Äù
One can never escape loneliness through another person; only through passion for life. Managing a relationship requires rationality. Freedom is inalienable. I once checked my ex‚Äôs phone‚ÄîI realized it was wrong and won‚Äôt do it again.

Understanding Strategy

This section mainly introduces the strategies of courting and how to maintain a good relationship‚Äîtrue wisdom. Never sacrifice your career for family. Don‚Äôt live with in-laws (though I think it depends). Have your own hobbies.

Understanding Marriage

Endure and stay loyal. As for non-marriage beliefs, there‚Äôs nothing more to say.

Understanding Setbacks

Every breakup is just making way for true love. Don‚Äôt force it. I love you, so I wish you well, even if I‚Äôm not the one by your side.
Do what you want regardless of others‚Äô opinions. Only care about those who matter to you.

Understanding Reading

What, Why, How. Keep reading. Don‚Äôt chase speed, but depth.

Understanding Romance

He shares sweet daily stories with his wife. If you don‚Äôt break up, you won‚Äôt discover how many better people there are out there. If you find one‚Äîlucky. If not‚Äîyou can still live happily on your own.
Live with emotional intelligence and the world becomes beautiful.

Understanding Socializing

Associate with decent people. Different people require different approaches. Rejecting others is an art. If you don‚Äôt have the guts to ask for your money back, don‚Äôt lend it.

Understanding Human Nature

I tend to be skeptical about human nature. You can‚Äôt control others, so just manage yourself. Don‚Äôt be vulgar.

Understanding Good and Evil

Some people enter your life just to teach you a lesson. Good or evil‚ÄîI prefer believing in others, as trust is given before it‚Äôs earned.
Even if deceived, it‚Äôs a lesson learned‚Äîdon‚Äôt fall into the same trap again. But don‚Äôt stop trusting altogether; kind people still exist.
God made the right hand a right hand as a reward; same for kind people‚Äîkindness is its own reward.
I recall being in a restroom without tissue once. I was going to ask a friend, but a stranger overheard and handed me tissues. Such kindness moved me deeply.
Kindness must come with principles‚Äîotherwise it may hurt others or yourself.

Understanding Wealth

The poor stay poor because of narrow thinking. To get rich, don‚Äôt just invest in your body‚Äîthink bigger. See the essence of problems.
Time is limited‚Äîhow to get rich fast? Find a subject you love, apply it, think broadly, and work in fields closely tied to society.

Understanding Society

Have ambition. Take one step at a time. Build an independent personality. Be accountable for your actions. Learn to transform your ability to feel happiness‚Äîthen change yourself.

Understanding Life and Death

Death studies include concepts like: No death, no life; face death to live; understand death to be reborn. Interesting and thought-provoking.
Knowing that we will die is what pushes us to live fully. When the time comes, I think I‚Äôll embrace death.

What the world lacks isn‚Äôt perfect people, but justice, sincerity, courage, and compassion from the heart. ‚Äî My biggest takeaway after watching Forever Young today.
We all know cause and effect‚Äîbut causes and effects come from relationships. Someday, I‚Äôll read Schopenhauer and Nietzsche properly.

Understanding Travel

This part recounts Mr. Zhuomo‚Äôs experiences in Tibet. Many dream of going there‚Äîmaybe because it helps people truly understand life‚Äôs struggles.
The US is less disciplined than the UK. Japan has great food culture and says ‚Äúsorry‚Äù a lot‚Äîavoiding bothering others.

Understanding Career

First learn to endure hardship. Then understand yourself and your talents. Begin with the end in mind and stay focused.

Understanding Education

Every child is born pure. Without proper education, they won‚Äôt become pillars of the nation.

Understanding Entertainment & Freedom

Life has two paths: one for career ambition‚Äîkeep passion; the other for living warmly‚Äîkeep humanity.
Open your eyes each day and tell yourself: Oh yeah!

entry.title: Frontend Interview Questions
entry.content:
Differences between var, let, and const?

‚úÖ Scope

  1. Variables declared with var do not have block scope. They can be accessed outside blocks but not outside functions.
  2. Variables declared with let have block scope, accessible only within the declared block.
  3. const defines constants, must be initialized, accessible only in the declared block, and cannot be reassigned.

‚úÖ Declaration Rules

  • A variable name can only be declared once using one of these methods; otherwise, it throws an error.

‚úÖ Difference when using with this

Featurevar / let / const
Can change this context‚úÖ Yes
First parameter is the object this refers to‚úÖ Yes
No object or undefined/nullDefaults to global window
Parameter passingapply uses array, call uses parameter list, bind supports multiple arguments
Execution methodapply/call execute immediately, bind returns a new function
What is event delegation?
  • Event delegation attaches events to a parent or ancestor element instead of individual child elements.
  • When the event reaches the target element, it bubbles up and triggers the handler on the outer element.
Difference between debounce and throttle?
  • Debounce: Executes only the last trigger. Even if the event keeps firing, it waits until n seconds after the last event to execute.
  • Throttle: Controls the execution frequency. Fires every n seconds during continuous event triggers.
How does frontend prevent SQL injection?
  1. Parameterized Queries: Use prepared statements or parameterized queries.
  2. Input Validation: Ensure user input follows expected format.
  3. Escape Special Characters: Escape characters when constructing SQL queries.
  4. Limit Permissions: Restrict user privileges to prevent unsafe operations.
  5. Whitelist Validation: Only allow expected values in input.
  6. Code Review: Regularly review code, especially DB-related parts.
Difference between HTTP and HTTPS
  1. HTTPS requires a certificate from a CA, which may cost money.
  2. HTTP transmits data in plaintext, while HTTPS uses SSL encryption.
  3. They use different connection methods and ports: HTTP uses 80, HTTPS uses 443.
  4. HTTP is stateless; HTTPS combines SSL + HTTP for encrypted, authenticated, secure communication.
Difference between created and mounted?
  • created runs before mounted. DOM is not fully rendered, but API requests can be made early here.
  • mounted is triggered when the DOM has been rendered, so it‚Äôs suitable for manipulating DOM elements.
Explain the event loop mechanism

üîÅ What is the Event Loop?

JavaScript is single-threaded. In addition to the call stack, it relies on task queues to control asynchronous code execution order.

This whole process is called the Event Loop.

üß† Core Concepts

  • Only one event loop in a single thread.
  • Multiple task queues:
    • Macro Tasks
    • Micro Tasks

‚è± Execution Order

Macro Task ‚ûù Clear all Micro Tasks ‚ûù Next Macro Task ‚ûù Clear all Micro Tasks‚Ä¶

  1. Execute a macro task (like the whole script)
  2. Execute all micro tasks created during this macro task
  3. If micro tasks generate more micro tasks, execute them too
  4. Begin the next macro task loop

üß© Examples of Macro Tasks

  • script
  • setTimeout
  • setInterval
  • setImmediate (Node.js)
  • I/O operations
  • UI rendering

üß¨ Examples of Micro Tasks

  • process.nextTick (Node.js, higher priority)
  • Promise.then / catch / finally
  • async / await
  • MutationObserver
Explain the CSS box model

The CSS box model includes IE and standard W3C models.

  • In standard W3C box model, width only includes content. box-sizing: content-box (default).
  • In IE box model, width includes content + padding + border. box-sizing: border-box.
  • box-sizing: padding-box includes left/right padding + width.
Differences between Vue 2 and Vue 3
  1. Two-way binding:
    • Vue 2: uses Object.defineProperty() (ES5), which only watches individual properties.
    • Vue 3: uses Proxy (ES6), which can observe entire objects and arrays.
  2. Lifecycle hooks:
    • Vue 2: beforeCreate, created, beforeMount, mounted, etc.
    • Vue 3: setup, onBeforeMount, onMounted, etc.
  3. Vue 2 requires a root tag; Vue 3 allows multiple root tags via Fragment.
  4. API:
    • Vue 2: Options API (functions and data handled separately).
    • Vue 3: Composition API (related code grouped together).
  5. Slots:
    • Named slot: Vue 2 uses slot="", Vue 3 uses v-slot="".
    • Scoped slot: Vue 2 uses slot-scope="data", Vue 3 uses #data or #default="{data}".

2. Register Runner Locally
